evidence_items.text: A tug driving instructor (tug instructor) and trainee tug driver (trainee driver) were seated beside each other in the tug. The flight crew were in communication with the headset operator via the aircraft’s interphone.
The trainee driver decided to stop the pushback and asked the tug instructor to take over.

After swapping seats the instructor recommenced the pushback, correcting the aircraft back onto the taxiway centreline. He continued to reassure and advise the trainee while performing the pushback, looking at her while doing so. The headset operator continued walking on the right side of the tug, abeam its cabin. The wingman was on the left just ahead of the tug.

The aircraft’s nosewheel reached the ‘Tug release point’ (TRP) ground markings. However, it continued moving beyond the TRP with its engine at idle and hit the blast barrier at the end of the cul-de-sac.
The tug instructor pulled the aircraft forward off the fence then stopped the tug.

The airport operator and ATC were notified. Soon after, representatives from the airport operator and the RFFS were on scene. The aircraft sustained substantial damage to the rear of the aircraft, including the APU, which was running at the time.
The TRP on Taxiway Delta is between Stands 61L and 61R. There is a 14.97 m clearance behind a B737-800 and the blast fence when its nosewheel is on the TRP.

The tug instructor stated that the method for getting a tug driver to stop quickly was to raise a clenched first, indicating the driver should apply the tug’s brakes. However, he suggested such a visual signal was not sufficient given a driver would be concentrating on the pushback, with the headset operator often out of his field of view. He did not receive any warning of the impending collision from the wingman or the headset operator.

Trainee tug driver The trainee driver was qualified as a headset operator and wingman, and was aware of the TRP through the training for these roles. This was her second pushback. The first was completed earlier that day, without event.

The trainee driver reported that she felt the tug slow down as the aircraft’s nose wheel approached the TRP, so believed the instructor would stop the pushback. However, she did not say anything when he drove past the TRP, assuming he must have known what he was doing. After the collision, she suggested not moving the aircraft off the blast fence.
Headset operator The headset operator was also qualified as a wingman. Prior to this accident, he knew about TRPs from his training for the headset operator role but had not physically seen one.

He commented that the tug instructor took over when the aircraft was abeam Stand 62 and thereafter was attending to talking to the trainee. The tug slowed down when the aircraft was abeam Stand 61, so he positioned himself to disconnect the tug from the aircraft when it stopped. However, the aircraft continued to move slowly until it hit the blast fence. He said he assumed the instructor had a reason for that and did not question his actions.

Wingman The wingman was also a qualified headset operator. On the day of the accident, he had been called into work at short notice. To avoid delaying the pushback, he had not collected the marshalling wands from the tug. Nevertheless, it was not mandatory to use them. He commented that the TRP was quite small.

roots_spec.exclusion_clause: Not explained by any other root
Not explained by any other root
Not explained by any other root
Not explained by any other root

slot_statements.availability: Communication/coordination breakdown among crew occurred during the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA flight on 12-25 in the hist_t3_prefinal phase.
slot_statements.defeater_resistance: The explanation of communication/coordination breakdown among crew is resistant to defeaters given the evidence from the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA 12-25 hist_t3_prefinal data, with no contradictory information undermining this cause.
slot_statements.fit_to_key_features: The communication/coordination breakdown among crew aligns with key features observed in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA 12-25 hist_t3_prefinal incident, such as timing, crew roles, and operational context.

node.statement: Communication/coordination breakdown among crew occurred during the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA flight on 12-25 in the hist_t3_prefinal phase.

assumptions: Crew communication includes verbal and non-verbal signals among tug instructor, trainee, headset operator, and wingman.
No mechanical failure evidence is present in the provided history.
defeaters: If evidence showed explicit, effective communication and challenge among crew preventing the incident, or if mechanical faults were confirmed.

quotes.exact_quote: He did not receive any warning of the impending collision from the wingman or the headset operator.
She did not say anything when he drove past the TRP, assuming he must have known what he was doing.
He said he assumed the instructor had a reason for that and did not question his actions.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence H8, H10, and H12 indicate lack of effective communication or challenge among crew during pushback, supporting a communication/coordination breakdown rather than procedural deviation or mechanical failure.
outcome.uncertainty_source: ambiguity in crew communication effectiveness and possible procedural deviations

slot_statements.availability: Mechanical/control failure was present and observable in the Boeing_737-8AS_9H-QAA_12-25:hist_t3_prefinal data.
slot_statements.defeater_resistance: Mechanical/control failure withstands potential defeaters within the Boeing_737-8AS_9H-QAA_12-25:hist_t3_prefinal context.
slot_statements.fit_to_key_features: Mechanical/control failure aligns with the key features identified in the Boeing_737-8AS_9H-QAA_12-25:hist_t3_prefinal scope.

node.statement: Mechanical/control failure was present and observable in the Boeing_737-8AS_9H-QAA_12-25:hist_t3_prefinal data.

defeaters: Direct evidence of mechanical or control system faults or bench checks indicating malfunction
Verified fault codes or repeat malfunctions in the aircraft control systems
Physical evidence of mechanical failure in the tug or aircraft controls

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence (H1-H3, H8, H10, H12) indicates the pushback was controlled by operators with no mention of mechanical faults; communication and procedural deviations are highlighted, and environmental factors (H7, H13) do not indicate mechanical failure. Thus, mechanical/control failure presence is contradicted.
outcome.uncertainty_source: absence of direct mechanical fault evidence; reliance on operator and procedural accounts

slot_statements.availability: The environmental or marking deficiency must be present and identifiable in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA during the hist_t3_prefinal inspection phase on 12-25.
slot_statements.defeater_resistance: The identification of the environmental or marking deficiency must be robust against potential defeaters or exceptions during the hist_t3_prefinal inspection of the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA.
slot_statements.fit_to_key_features: The environmental or marking deficiency should correspond to the key features and criteria defined for the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA in the hist_t3_prefinal inspection phase.

node.statement: The environmental or marking deficiency must be present and identifiable in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA during the hist_t3_prefinal inspection phase on 12-25.

assumptions: The TRP marking described in H7 and H13 corresponds to the environmental or marking deficiency in question.
No direct evidence states the marking was missing or not identifiable during the hist_t3_prefinal inspection phase.
defeaters: If evidence showed the TRP marking was missing, obscured, or not identifiable during the inspection phase, or if multiple crew members reported inability to see or identify the marking.

quotes.exact_quote: The TRP on Taxiway Delta is between Stands 61L and 61R. There is a 14.97 m clearance behind a B737-800 and the blast fence when its nosewheel is on the TRP.
He commented that the TRP was quite small.

The tug instructor stated that the method for getting a tug driver to stop quickly was to raise a clenched first, indicating the driver should apply the tug’s brakes. However, he suggested such a visual signal was not sufficient given a driver would be concentrating on the pushback, with the headset operator often out of his field of view.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence H7 and H13 describe the TRP marking as present and identifiable, though small, and H8 indicates procedural issues with signaling rather than marking deficiency, favoring procedural deviation over environmental deficiency.
outcome.uncertainty_source: ambiguity in whether the marking was sufficiently visible or adequate for safe operation; no direct statement of marking deficiency.

slot_statements.availability: The procedural deviation in pushback execution is documented and available in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA 12-25 historical prefinal records.
slot_statements.defeater_resistance: The procedural deviation in pushback execution withstands scrutiny against potential defeaters within the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA 12-25 historical prefinal context.
slot_statements.fit_to_key_features: The procedural deviation in pushback execution aligns with the key features identified for the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA 12-25 pushback operations in the historical prefinal phase.

node.statement: The procedural deviation in pushback execution is documented and available in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA 12-25 historical prefinal records.

assumptions: Historical prefinal records include the detailed history items provided (H1-H13)
The documented history items represent the available records for the incident
No contradictory documentation exists outside the provided evidence
defeaters: If records or logs explicitly documenting the procedural deviation were missing or contradicted by other official sources
If evidence showed mechanical faults or environmental markings were inadequate causing the incident
If communication breakdown evidence was stronger indicating lack of coordination rather than procedural deviation

Discriminators favor procedural deviation over communication breakdown, environment deficiency, or mechanical failure.
outcome.uncertainty_source: No explicit mention of formal documentation availability in the historical records; assumption that historical records exist and are accessible.

node.statement: The communication/coordination breakdown among crew aligns with key features observed in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA 12-25 hist_t3_prefinal incident, such as timing, crew roles, and operational context.

assumptions: Assuming that the lack of warnings from wingman and headset operator indicates communication/coordination breakdown.
Assuming no mechanical faults contributed given no evidence of hardware failure.
defeaters: If evidence showed clear procedural deviation with explicit stop signals ignored, or hardware faults causing uncontrolled movement, the interpretation might shift.
If environmental or marking deficiencies were proven to be the primary cause, the communication breakdown alignment would weaken.

node.statement: The explanation of communication/coordination breakdown among crew is resistant to defeaters given the evidence from the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA 12-25 hist_t3_prefinal data, with no contradictory information undermining this cause.

assumptions: No mechanical or environmental failures occurred beyond what is documented
Crew communication and coordination issues are primary cause given no contradictory evidence
defeaters: If evidence emerged of mechanical faults or hardware failures (contradicting H4, H8)
If marking deficiencies or environmental factors were shown to cause confusion (contradicting H7, H13)
If procedural deviations were clearly the primary cause rather than communication breakdown

children_spec.statement: Crew members were not reachable via radio or interphone during critical phases
children_spec.test_procedure: Check radio and interphone communication logs and recordings for availability and response times during the incident

children_spec.statement: Communication devices (radios, interphones) were operational and powered on

children_spec.statement: Crew members were physically present and able to use communication devices when needed
children_spec.test_procedure: Review crew positioning and activity logs or cockpit voice recordings to verify presence and ability to communicate

children_spec.statement: The procedural deviation is not corrected or mitigated by the flight crew during pushback

node.statement: The environmental or marking deficiency should correspond to the key features and criteria defined for the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA in the hist_t3_prefinal inspection phase.

assumptions: The TRP marking adequacy and visibility are critical key features for environmental or marking deficiency assessment.
Crew statements about visual signals and marking size reflect actual conditions during the incident.
defeaters: If evidence showed the TRP markings were adequate and clearly visible to all crew members, or if procedural errors fully explained the incident without marking issues.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence H7, H8, and H13 describe the TRP marking size and visibility issues, supporting that the environmental or marking deficiency corresponds to key features for the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA in the hist_t3_prefinal phase.
outcome.uncertainty_source: Some ambiguity exists about the sufficiency of visual signals and marking visibility, but evidence leans toward marking deficiency.

node.statement: The procedural deviation is not corrected or mitigated by the flight crew during pushback

assumptions: The tug instructor is considered part of the flight crew for procedural correction purposes
No unseen corrective actions occurred beyond those reported in evidence
defeaters: If evidence showed timely corrective action or communication by the flight crew during pushback
If environmental or mechanical factors prevented correction despite crew efforts

quotes.exact_quote: The aircraft’s nosewheel reached the ‘Tug release point’ (TRP) ground markings. However, it continued moving beyond the TRP with its engine at idle and hit the blast barrier at the end of the cul-de-sac.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence H4 and H5 show the aircraft passed the TRP and hit the blast barrier, with the tug instructor stopping only after impact. H8, H10, and H12 indicate no corrective communication or intervention by crew during pushback, supporting the claim that the procedural deviation was not corrected or mitigated.
outcome.uncertainty_source: No explicit statements about crew intent or awareness during the deviation; possible ambiguity in communication effectiveness

node.statement: Ground personnel do not detect or intervene to prevent the procedural deviation during pushback

defeaters: If evidence showed ground personnel actively warned or intervened to stop the deviation.

quotes.exact_quote: He did not receive any warning of the impending collision from the wingman or the headset operator.
She did not say anything when he drove past the TRP, assuming he must have known what he was doing.
He said he assumed the instructor had a reason for that and did not question his actions.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence H8, H10, and H12 directly indicate that ground personnel (wingman and headset operator) did not detect or intervene to prevent the procedural deviation during pushback, supporting the claim.
outcome.uncertainty_source: None significant; evidence clearly states lack of intervention.

node.statement: Crew members were not reachable via radio or interphone during critical phases

defeaters: If evidence showed radio or interphone communication was lost or crew unreachable during critical phases.

quotes.exact_quote: The flight crew were in communication with the headset operator via the aircraft’s interphone.
He did not receive any warning of the impending collision from the wingman or the headset operator.
He said he assumed the instructor had a reason for that and did not question his actions.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence H1 shows flight crew were in communication via interphone; H8 and H12 indicate no communication failure or unreachability during critical phases, contradicting the claim.
outcome.uncertainty_source: none

node.statement: Aircraft systems or safety mechanisms fail to alert or prevent the procedural deviation during pushback

assumptions: Assuming that the absence of warnings from wingman and headset operator implies failure of alert mechanisms rather than human error or communication issues.
defeaters: If there was evidence of a mechanical control failure or environmental marking deficiency causing the deviation, or if communication breakdown was proven to be the primary cause, this would change the assessment.

quotes.exact_quote: The tug instructor stated that the method for getting a tug driver to stop quickly was to raise a clenched first, indicating the driver should apply the tugs brakes. However, he suggested such a visual signal was not sufficient given a driver would be concentrating on the pushback, with the headset operator often out of his field of view. He did not receive any warning of the impending collision from the wingman or the headset operator.

He commented that the tug instructor took over when the aircraft was abeam Stand 62 and thereafter was attending to talking to the trainee. The tug slowed down when the aircraft was abeam Stand 61, so he positioned himself to disconnect the tug from the aircraft when it stopped. However, the aircraft continued to move slowly until it hit the blast fence. He said he assumed the instructor had a reason for that and did not question his actions.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence H8 and H12 directly indicate that no alert or safety mechanism prevented the procedural deviation during pushback, supporting the claim that systems or mechanisms failed to alert or prevent the deviation.
outcome.uncertainty_source: ambiguity in the effectiveness of visual signals and lack of explicit system alert evidence

children_spec.test_procedure: Review the pushback checklist and verify if all steps were completed as per procedure

children_spec.statement: The ground personnel communicated all required instructions clearly and timely during pushback
children_spec.test_procedure: Examine communication recordings and logs between ground personnel and flight crew during pushback

children_spec.statement: The pushback equipment was functioning correctly and used according to manufacturer guidelines
children_spec.test_procedure: Inspect maintenance records and operational logs of pushback equipment used during the event

children_spec.statement: Environmental conditions during pushback did not interfere with procedural compliance
children_spec.test_procedure: Analyze weather and environmental data at the time of pushback for factors affecting procedure adherence

children_spec.statement: Mechanical components required for control are physically present on the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA

children_spec.statement: Mechanical control components are installed correctly and connected as per design specifications
children_spec.test_procedure: Perform a detailed inspection and verification of installation and connections against design documentation; incorrect installation would lower the probability

children_spec.statement: Mechanical control components are free from physical damage or wear that would impair their function
children_spec.test_procedure: Conduct a physical examination and non-destructive testing to detect damage or wear; evidence of damage would lower the probability

children_spec.statement: Mechanical control components are not obstructed or jammed, allowing full range of motion

node.statement: Crew members were physically present and able to use communication devices when needed

defeaters: If evidence showed crew were physically absent or unable to use communication devices when needed
If communication devices were malfunctioning or not used

quotes.exact_quote: A tug driving instructor (tug instructor) and trainee tug driver (trainee driver) were seated beside each other in the tug. The flight crew were in communication with the headset operator via the aircraft’s interphone.
The trainee driver decided to stop the pushback and asked the tug instructor to take over.

After swapping seats the instructor recommenced the pushback, correcting the aircraft back onto the taxiway centreline. He continued to reassure and advise the trainee while performing the pushback, looking at her while doing so. The headset operator continued walking on the right side of the tug, abeam its cabin. The wingman was on the left just ahead of the tug.

The tug instructor stated that the method for getting a tug driver to stop quickly was to raise a clenched first, indicating the driver should apply the tug’s brakes. However, he suggested such a visual signal was not sufficient given a driver would be concentrating on the pushback, with the headset operator often out of his field of view. He did not receive any warning of the impending collision from the wingman or the headset operator.

The trainee driver reported that she felt the tug slow down as the aircraft’s nose wheel approached the TRP, so believed the instructor would stop the pushback. However, she did not say anything when he drove past the TRP, assuming he must have known what he was doing.

He commented that the tug instructor took over when the aircraft was abeam Stand 62 and thereafter was attending to talking to the trainee. The tug slowed down when the aircraft was abeam Stand 61, so he positioned himself to disconnect the tug from the aircraft when it stopped. However, the aircraft continued to move slowly until it hit the blast fence. He said he assumed the instructor had a reason for that and did not question his actions.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence (H1, H2, H3, H8, H10, H12) shows crew members were physically present and able to use communication devices, supporting the claim. The discriminator disc:R1_PUSHBACK_PROCEDURAL_DEVIATION|R2_COMMUNICATION_BREAKDOWN favors communication breakdown over procedural deviation, consistent with the claim.
outcome.uncertainty_source: None significant; evidence directly supports claim

node.statement: The identification of the environmental or marking deficiency must be robust against potential defeaters or exceptions during the hist_t3_prefinal inspection of the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA.

assumptions: The TRP marking is considered part of the environmental or marking deficiency
The robustness against defeaters includes effective communication and clear visual cues
defeaters: If there was evidence that the TRP was clearly visible and unambiguous to all crew members
If communication protocols or signals were effective and consistently used
If the headset operator or wingman had actively warned the tug instructor of the impending collision

quotes.exact_quote: The TRP on Taxiway Delta is between Stands 61L and 61R. There is a 14.97 m clearance behind a B737-800 and the blast fence when its nosewheel is on the TRP.

The tug instructor stated that the method for getting a tug driver to stop quickly was to raise a clenched first, indicating the driver should apply the tug’s brakes. However, he suggested such a visual signal was not sufficient given a driver would be concentrating on the pushback, with the headset operator often out of his field of view. He did not receive any warning of the impending collision from the wingman or the headset operator.
He commented that the TRP was quite small.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence H7, H8, and H13 indicate that the environmental marking (TRP) was present but small and that communication signals to stop the tug were insufficient, supporting that the identification of the environmental or marking deficiency was not robust against defeaters during the inspection.
outcome.uncertainty_source: ambiguity in the adequacy and visibility of the TRP marking and communication effectiveness

children_spec.statement: Required environmental markings are physically present at the location
children_spec.test_procedure: Inspect the location to verify the presence of all required environmental markings

children_spec.statement: Required environmental markings are visible and legible under operational conditions
children_spec.test_procedure: Assess visibility and legibility of markings during typical operational lighting and weather conditions

children_spec.statement: Required environmental markings are maintained and not obscured or damaged
children_spec.test_procedure: Examine markings for signs of wear, damage, or obstruction that would reduce their effectiveness

node.statement: Mechanical control components are installed correctly and connected as per design specifications

assumptions: No mechanical faults were reported or observed in the evidence.
Operator statements accurately reflect the mechanical condition of the control components.
defeaters: Direct evidence of mechanical control component faults or installation errors would change the assessment.
Verified fault codes or repeat malfunctions indicating mechanical failure.

However, he suggested such a visual signal was not sufficient given a driver would be concentrating on the pushback, with the headset operator often out of his field of view. He did not receive any warning of the impending collision from the wingman or the headset operator.

He commented that the tug instructor took over when the aircraft was abeam Stand 62 and thereafter was attending to talking to the trainee. The tug slowed down when the aircraft was abeam Stand 61, so he positioned himself to disconnect the tug from the aircraft when it stopped. However, the aircraft continued to move slowly until it hit the blast fence. He said he assumed the instructor had a reason for that and did not question his actions.

node.statement: Required environmental markings are visible and legible under operational conditions

assumptions: Presence of TRP marking implies visibility and legibility under operational conditions.
No evidence indicates markings were obscured or illegible.
defeaters: If evidence showed the TRP markings were obscured, damaged, or illegible under operational conditions.
If crew or operators reported inability to see or interpret the markings during pushback.
